awd_titl_txt: EarthCube Data Infrastructure:  Collaborative Proposal:   A unified experimental-natural digital data system for analysis of rock microstructures
awd_abstract_narration:
When viewed at the micro-scale, rocks reveal structures that help to interpret the processes and forces responsible for their formation.  These microstructures help to explain phenomena that occur at the scale of mountains and tectonic plates.  Interpretation of microstructures formed in nature during deformation is aided by comparison with those formed during experiments, under known conditions of pressure, temperature, stress, strain and strain rate, and experimental rock deformation benefits from the ground truth offered through comparison with rocks deformed in nature.  However, the ability to search for relevant naturally or experimentally deformed microstructures is hindered by the lack of any database that contains these data.  The researchers collaborating on this project will develop a single digital data system for rock microstructures to facilitate the critical interaction between and among the communities that study naturally and experimentally deformed rocks.  To aid in the comparison of microstructures formed in nature and experiment, we will link to commonly used analytical tools and develop a pilot project for automatic comparison of microstructures using machine learning.   

Rock microstructures relate processes at the microscopic scale to phenomena at the outcrop, orogen, and plate scales and reveal the relationships among stress, strain, and strain rate.  Quantitative rheological information is obtained through linked studies of naturally formed microstructures with those created during rock deformation experiments under known conditions.  The project will develop a single digital data system for both naturally and experimentally deformed rock microstructure data to facilitate comparison of microstructures from different environments.  A linked data system will facilitate interaction between practitioners of experimental deformation, those studying natural deformation and the cyberscience community.  The data system will leverage the StraboSpot data system currently under development in Structural Geology and Tectonics.  To develop this system requires: 1) Modification of the StraboSpot data system to accept microstructural data from both naturally and experimentally deformed rocks; and 2) Linking the microstructural data to its geologic context ? either in nature, or its experimental data/parameters.  The researchers will engage the rock deformation community with the goal of establishing data standards and protocols for data collection, and integrate our work with ongoing efforts to establish protocols and techniques for automated metadata collection and digital data storage.  To analyze the microstructures studied and/or generated by these communities, we will ensure StraboSpot data output is compatible with commonly used microstructural tools.  They will develop a pilot project for comparing and analyzing microstructures from different environments using machine-learning.

por.por_cntn:
Geologists routinely study rocks that have been deformed due to the motion of tectonic plates. These deformed rocks record important clues about Earth’s history (for example, how were the first continents formed?) and future processes relevant to humans (for example, how earthquakes occur?). This research aimed to develop a digital data system for cataloging data (images, physical properties, etc.) from deformed rocks. This system will facilitate data availability and sharing, both between disciplinary scientists and with the public. In essence, the data system allows scientists to do better science.

 

Typically, rocks collected from outcrops in the field are taken back to a laboratory, cut into thin slices (about one-half the width of a human hair), and then glued to a glass slide. This “thin section” of rock is used for a variety of analyses which allow geologists to determine rock history and properties. In addition, a group of scientists experimentally deform rocks in the lab under controlled conditions. The difficulty with this approach is that rocks deform very slowly in nature due to tectonic processes. In contrast, deformation in the lab necessarily occurs much more rapidly (we cannot wait millions of years for the results!). To determine if these experiments apply to the geological conditions rocks experience beneath the Earth’s surface, scientists who conduct rock deformation experiments also make thin sections of their experimentally deformed rock samples and compare them to naturally deformed rocks from field geologists. In this way, they can determine if their experiments are relevant to natural Earth processes. Conversely, field-based geologists want to interpret the conditions that prevailed during the deformation of natural samples within the Earth, which often relies on comparing the thin section scale characteristics of the natural samples with those resulting from experiments under known conditions. In short, practitioners from both the natural and experimental rock deformation communities rely on each other’s data. This digital data system for data from deformed rocks, from nature and experiments, allows them to share them.

 

We used the existing StraboSpot data system as the basis of our work, which was developed principally for data from field-based geologists. The work involved modifying the StraboSpot data system to accept microstructural data from naturally and experimentally deformed rocks. Further, it required that the communities agree on the types of data required and the vocabulary and standards for the terms in the data system. Development of controlled vocabulary and workflow for microstructural and experimental data was done through community workshops. Further, we have worked internationally to ensure that the standards used could be adopted in Europe. 

 

There are two major products of this grant. First, we have developed a digital data system (StraboMicro) that allows thin section information to be recorded and saved. This system is built to host community tools designed to analyze these thin sections. Second, we are building an interface for the experimental community to enter the result of rock-deformation experiments specific to the types of instruments used by various researchers. Both of these products are planned to be released in 2021.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: J. Douglas Walker
